correction.p: This electronic text file was created by optical character recognition (OCR). OCR errors have not been corrected.
Illegible text in the original is indicated using unclear or gap, as appropriate. If corrected, the reference source is incidated with supplied.

normalization.p: Original spelling is preserved. When noticed, obvious misspellings are combined with the correct spelling as choice in the TEI. Ligatures are reproduced as multiple letters. Original footnote and marginal note sigla are replaced with sequential numbers for each entry.

punctuation.p: Extra space around punctuation marks is removed.

quotation.p: Quotation marks are retained as content in the text. Redundant open quotation marks at the start of lines inside block quotes are silently removed.

segmentation.p: The div type="entry" element divides the text into individual entries.
The div type="section" and div type="subsection" elements are reserved for entry subsections.

list.item: Encoding has been done using the recommendations for Level 3 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines.
Individual entries and page-breaks are encoded, but column breaks are omitted.
Running headers and side descriptions are not included.
Some font formatting is preserved: italic, small caps, strike through, subscript, superscript, underline. The following formatting is ignored: bold, font size, typeface.

projectDesc.p: All text was encoded for the Nineteenth-Century Knowledge Project to provide a machine-readable edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica to analyze.
Subject-level metadata was added to each entry using the HIVE automated vocabulary server created by the Metadata Research Center at Drexel University (https://hive2.cci.drexel.edu).

samplingDecl.p: This release reproduces the text matter for all entries. It does not include images, tables, formulae, front- or back-matter. It omits volume 1, which consists of "Dissertations" rather than entries.

div.p: CAP, a part of dress made to cover the head. The origin of eaps and hats is referred to the year 1449, the first seen in these parts of the world being at the entry of Charles VII. into Rouen; but from that time they began to take plaee of the hoods, or chaperoons, whieh had until then been used. When the eap was of velvet they ealled it mortier, when of wool simply bonnet. None but kings, prinees, and knights, were allowed the use of the mortier. The cap was the head-dress of the clergy and graduates. Pasquier says that it was aneiently a part of the hood worn by the people of the robe, the skirts of whieh being cut off as an eneumbrance, left the round eap an easy and commodious eover for the head; whieh round cap being afterwards assumed by the people, those of the gown ehanged it for a square one, first invented by a Frenchman ealled Patrouillet. He adds, that the giving of the cap to the students in the universities denoted that they had acquired full liberty, and were no longer subjeet to the rod of their superiors; in imitation of the ancient Romans, who gave a pileus or cap to their slaves, in the eeremony of making them free; and hence the proverb, Vocareservos adpileum. Henee, also, on medals, the cap is the symbol of Liberty, whom they represent as holding in her right hand a cap by the point.

The Romans were many ages without any regular covering for the head. When either the rain or sun proved troublesome, the lappet of the gown was thrown over the head; and henee it is that all the ancient statues appear bareheaded, excepting sometimes a wreath or the like. And the same usage obtained among the Greeks, at least during the heroie age, when no eaps were known. The sort of caps or covers of the head in use among the Romans, on divers occasions, were the pitra, pileus,cucullus, galerus, and palliolum; the differences between which are often eonfounded by ancient as well as modern writers.

The French elergy wear a shallow kind of cap called calotte, whieh only covers the top of the head, and is made of leather, satin, worsted, or other stuff. The red cap is a mark of dignity, allowed only to those who are raised to the dignity of cardinal. The secular clergy are distinguish^ ed by blaek leathern caps, the regulars by knit and worsted ones.

Churchmen, and the members of universities, students in law, physie, and others, as well as graduates, wear square caps. In most universities doctors are distinguished by peculiar eaps, whieh are given them on assuming their degree. Wiekliff calls the eanons of his time bifurcati, from their eaps. Pasquier observes that in his time the eaps worn by the churehmen and others were called square eaps, though in effect they were round yellow caps.

The cap is sometimes used as a mark of infamy. In Italy generally the Jews are distinguished by a yellow eap, but at Lucea by an orange one. In France, those who had been bankrupts were obliged ever after to wear a green cap, to prevent people from being imposed on by them in any future transaction. By several arrets in 1584, 1622, 1628, and 1688, it was deereed, that if they were at any time found without their green cap, their protection should be null, and their creditors empowered to cast them into prison; but the sentence is not now executed.

Capof Maintenance, one of the regalia, or ornaments of state, belonging to the kings of England, before whom it was carried at the coronation and other great solemnities. Caps of maintenance are also carried before the mayors of the several eities in England.

Cap and Button Isles, two small islands in the Straits of Sunda, which are supposed to be of voleanic origin. They are round in their figure, and their sides are steep and have a naked appearanee. One of them, the Cap, is penetrated by two large eaverns running horizontally into the rock, whieh are famous for producing the edible bird-nests so highly prized by the Chinese, and which constitute a great article of traffic. Long. 105. 48. E. Lat. 5. 49. S.
